sub_topic: Finding the Ramsey number of a graph.
message_2:
The Ramsey number R(m, n) is the smallest integer R such that any graph with R vertices will contain either a clique of size m (a complete subgraph with m vertices) or an independent set of size n (a set of n vertices with no edges between them).

To find R(3, 4), we will use the inequality R(m, n) ≤ R(m - 1, n) + R(m, n - 1) for m, n ≥ 2.

First, we need to find the values of R(2, 4) and R(3, 3).

R(2, 4) is the smallest integer R such that any graph with R vertices will contain either a clique of size 2 (an edge) or an independent set of size 4 (four vertices with no edges between them). Since any graph with at least 4 vertices will have either an edge or an independent set of size 4, R(2, 4) = 4.

R(3, 3) is the smallest integer R such that any graph with R vertices will contain either a clique of size 3 (a triangle) or an independent set of size 3 (three vertices with no edges between them). It is known that R(3, 3) = 6.

Now, we can use the inequality to find R(3, 4):

R(3, 4) ≤ R(2, 4) + R(3, 3)
R(3, 4) ≤ 4 + 6
R(3, 4) ≤ 10

It is known that R(3, 4) = 9 because there exists a graph with 8 vertices, called the Clebsch graph, which does not contain a triangle or an independent set of size 4. Therefore, the smallest integer R that guarantees the existence of either a triangle or an independent set of size 4 is 9.

So, R(3, 4) = 9.
